head.title: Compact ATR–WGS-Integrated Bioethanol Fuel Processor for Portable and On-board Fuel Cell Applications | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Compact ATR–WGS-Integrated Bioethanol Fuel Processor for Portable and On-board Fuel Cell Applications

A compact bioethanol fuel processor with an all-in-one design of the auto-thermal reforming (ATR) and water-gas-shift (WGS) reactors was developed. The fuel processor has unique features, such as the annular-type reactors which are constructed by stacking disk-shaped Rh/Gd-doped-ceria-coated structured catalysts and insertion of an internal heat exchanger between the two reactors. This integration renders two distinctive temperature zones for the ATR and WGS reactions in the fuel processor with a total volume of 135 cm3. A hydrogen production rate of 30 sccm H2/mLreactor, equivalent to ca. 2.3 kWe/Lreactor, and a CO level of 2.4–2.7 mol % (dry basis) were achieved under continuous long-term operation for 700 h. The as-produced gas is ready-to-use in high-temperature polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells, and this combination can be a competitive solution for hydrogen mobility requiring high energy storage density.

div.p:
A compact bioethanol fuel processor with an all-in-one design of the auto-thermal reforming (ATR) and water-gas-shift (WGS) reactors was developed. The fuel processor has unique features, such as the annular-type reactors which are constructed by stacking disk-shaped Rh/Gd-doped-ceria-coated structured catalysts and insertion of an internal heat exchanger between the two reactors. This integration renders two distinctive temperature zones for the ATR and WGS reactions in the fuel processor with a total volume of 135 cm
3
. A hydrogen production rate of 30 sccm H
2
/mL
reactor
, equivalent to ca. 2.3 kW
e
/L
reactor
, and a CO level of 2.4–2.7 mol % (dry basis) were achieved under continuous long-term operation for 700 h. The as-produced gas is ready-to-use in high-temperature polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells, and this combination can be a competitive solution for hydrogen mobility requiring high energy storage density.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: The developed compact bioethanol fuel processor for fuel cells provides a competitive and sustainable solution for hydrogen mobility.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Amid an accelerating transition to low-carbon-emission vehicles, hydrogen-powered fuel cells have attracted increasing attention, especially in the heavy-duty vehicle sector.
(1,2)
To meet the increasing demand for hydrogen for vehicles, alternative or complementary methods including pressurized hydrogen storage, on-board hydrogen production from fossil fuels, and chemical hydrides have been pursued.
(3)
One of the promising fuel candidates, renewable bioethanol, can play a crucial role because it has a high hydrogen storage capacity (13.1 wt %), low toxicity, the potential to achieve carbon neutrality, and compatibility with existing distribution infrastructure.
(4−6)
On-board ethanol-based fuel processers have been developed during the last decades owing to their increased demand for hydrogen production for mixed combustion
(7,8)
and in the drive-range extender for hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicles.
(9−12)

Despite these advantages, ethanol reforming has several issues when applied to on-board hydrogen production systems. Its higher reaction temperatures than methanol reforming heighten the vulnerability of reactor components to thermal degradation, especially in highly integrated mobile hardware configurations. Also, converting ethanol into H
2
-rich gas for polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) needs multistage downstream processes to abate the CO concentration including high-temperature WGS (HTWGS), low-temperature WGS (LTWGS), preferential CO oxidation, and/or methanation. It also implies increased complexity for the thermal integration of reactors and heat exchangers. Fortunately, stringent requirements for CO concentration can be mitigated when high-temperature PEMFCs (HTPEMFCs) are coupled with the fuel processors. While low-temperature PEMFCs operating below 100 °C can tolerate CO levels of up to 20–50 ppmv,
(10)
HTPEMFCs operating above 120 °C can withstand higher CO concentrations of 2–5%.
(13)
These CO levels can be easily achieved by simpler processor configurations, for example, a combination of ethanol reforming and HTWGS.
(14)
Owing to continued development in HTPEMFCs, several kW-level HTPEMFC systems (e.g., SerEnergy, AixCellSys, and Ultracell) are now plausible options with couplings with an ethanol-based hydrogen generator.
(14)

Proper selection of the catalyst for efficient hydrogen extraction from bioethanol is one of the technological keys. Among various metallic active phases, Rh has been widely utilized because of its higher catalytic activity for both ethanol reforming
(15−21)
and WGS.
(22−24)
In respect of supports, ceria (CeO
2
)
(25,26)
has been widely accepted as support coupled with Rh due to its high affinity to Rh
(27)
and oxygen storage capacity (OSC), while Zr-doped ceria
(28−30)
and Gd-doped ceria (GDC)
(19,31)
have been widely investigated as an enhanced support because of their high catalytic activity and resistance to carbon formation as a result of their superior OSC from additional oxygen vacancies and thermal stability. In this study, Rh/GDC-coated structured catalysts were applied to both the auto-thermal reforming (ATR) and WGS reactors.

The design and development of a compact unit of the ethanol fuel processor have gained notable attention through a demonstration work of Kolb et al.
(32)
Additionally, Aicher et al. showcased a portable fuel processor with a complete and automated configuration with ATR, HTWGS, LTWGS, a tail combustor, PEMFC, and system control units. Note that they underscored the necessity for a high degree of integration of such systems to apply to mobile and stand-alone applications.
(10)
Gardemann et al. designed and demonstrated an ethanol fuel processor including ATR, WGS, and catalytic burner with 200–500 W electrical power output and
X
CO
< 1.5% at a steady state operation,
(33)
while mentioning that a smaller fuel processor with a simplified component configuration is worth further development and the coupling with HTPEMFC is necessary. Therefore, the primary objective of this work is to make bioethanol processors compact for hydrogen supply and to verify whether the as-proposed concept is applicable to on-board HTPEMFC applications.

In this paper, we present the successful demonstration of a 126 W [lower heating value (LHV) basis] ethanol fuel processor for HTPEMFCs. This paper deals comprehensively with the fabrication of structured catalysts, catalytic activity tests toward ATR and HTWGS, and the design and testing of the integrated fuel processor. To realize an on-board applicable compact-type reactor for multiple-step reactions, the as-developed processor is composed of the annular-type ATR reactor (based on
eq 1
) and WGS reactor (
eq 2
) and an internal heat exchanger connecting the two reactors. This configuration permits temperature uniformity in each reactor, while maintaining two distinctive temperature zones for ATR and WGS. The highly compact fuel processor achieved a high hydrogen production rate of 30 sccm H
2
/mL
reactor
with a low CO level (2.4–2.7 mol %) during continuous operation for 700 h. Finally, we evaluated the suitability of the gases produced from the as-developed fuel processor for HTPEMFCs.
(1)
(2)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 2.1. Design of the Integrated Ethanol Fuel Processor
div.div:
For transport and portable applications, fuel processors are required to satisfy the following criteria, which consist of light and miniaturized modules with a minimal number of components; have fast start-up capabilities without the need for laborious pretreatments of catalysts prior to start-up; and exhibit reliable operation and load-following capabilities under extreme operating conditions (e.g., sub-zero temperatures).
(10,34)
In this regard, the as-developed ethanol fuel processor possesses several aspects suitable for portable applications, namely, the ATR for ethanol reforming, the annular-type ATR–WGS-integrated reactor, and the disk-shaped structured catalyst. Each of these aspects is discussed in more detail in the following paragraphs.

ATR [i.e., oxidative steam reforming (SR)] is a combination of catalytic partial oxidation (CPOX) and SR. The ATR reforming process is more suitable than CPOX and SR for portable power generation applications. CPOX, which involves ethanol combustion with a sub-stoichiometric amount of oxygen,
(10)
is unfavorable because of the formation of coke and soot, acetaldehyde, and ethylene caused by flames generated during the reaction and the relatively high CO concentration of the reformate.
(18)
SR can alleviate these problems associated with CPOX by using steam instead of oxygen. However, it is an endothermic process, requiring integration with external components including heating sources (e.g., combustor and electric heater) and heat exchangers with large heat transfer areas. Therefore, SR is appropriate for large stationary power generation systems with less-strict requirements in terms of volume, weight, and start-up time.
(10)
In mobile applications, ATR confers advantages such as a relatively simpler system configuration and shorter start-up time, by combining a combustion zone with a reforming zone.

The annular-type ATR-HTWGS-integrated reactor is another distinct feature of the integrated fuel processor. Because precise temperature controls in both reactors are instrumental, we adopted the annular-type reactors in both ATR and WGS. In general, the annular-type reactor is capable of maintaining minimal temperature gradients in the radial direction and enables faster heat transfer between the heat source and the heat sink.
(35,36)
Although HTPEMFCs are highly resistant to CO poisoning, a reduction in CO concentration is always preferred to widen the operative temperature range and increase the stack/system efficiency, which are enabled by precise control of the HTWGS reaction. HTWGS requires a lower reaction temperature than ATR; the HTWGS and ATR reactors have operating temperatures of 350–500 and 600–800 °C, respectively (
Figure
1
). To establish these two distinctive temperature ranges, the internal heat exchanger was inserted between the two reactors. The ATR outlet gas is cooled in the internal heat exchanger built inside the fuel processor before being delivered to the WGS reactor. Additionally, the fresh reactants are preheated in the internal heat exchanger before being supplied to the ATR reactor.

div.p: Figure 1. Concept of ATR–WGS-integrated ethanol fuel processor: schematic of the ethanol ATR–WGS-integrated reformer and equilibrium composition as a function of temperature [isothermal conditions with steam-to-carbon ratio (S/C) = 2.5 and oxygen-to-carbon ratio (O/C) = 0.5, methanation is not taken into consideration in equilibrium calculation].

div.div:
The third main advantage concerns the disk-shaped structured catalyst. The usage of noble catalysts (Ru, Pt, Pd, Rh, etc.) is justifiable in mobile fuel processors because of the superior catalytic activities required for higher hydrogen production rates at a given volume, the simpler operative protocols that do not require activation or reduction of the catalyst before start-up of the system, and their higher redox stability.
(37)
Therefore, in this study, Rh/GDC was chosen because of its higher activity in both ATR and WGS reactions. For facile and uniform catalyst coating in the reactors, disk-shaped structured catalysts were stacked in the annular reactors.

0.5 wt % Rh on GDC (Praxair, US) was wash-coated on FeCr alloy (FeCrAlloy) supports. FeCrAlloy fiber mats (Fibertech, Korea) with several through-holes were fabricated into disk form with outer/inner diameters and thicknesses of 3.2, 1, and 0.15 cm. This disk-shaped support was pretreated at 1,000 °C for 2 h in air, leading to the formation of α-Al
2
O
3
on the surface of FeCrAlloy.
(38)
A slurry comprised of Rh/GDC powder, polyvinyl-pyrrolidone, PEG400 (polyethylene 400), Butvar B-98 (Polyvinyl Butyral Resin), and ethanol was prepared for wash-coating. The supports were dipped into the slurry, sonicated for 90 min, and dried at 80 °C. The coating process was repeated several times to increase catalyst loading, and finally, the structured catalysts were calcined at 800 °C for 3 h. The amount of Rh/GDC coated on the support reached ca. 2 g
Rh/GDC
/cm
3
for each disk, evidenced by measuring weight difference before and after the coating.

div.h3: 2.3. Catalytic Activity Tests of Structured Catalysts in ATR and WGS Reactions
div.div:
To determine the optimal volumes of the structured catalyst and operating temperatures required for 126 W (LHV basis) ethanol fuel processor, catalytic activities in the ATR and WGS reactions were tested by changing the temperature and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV, h
–1
). The tests were performed in an apparatus customized for the disk-shaped catalyst, which is shown in
Figure
2
. Reaction gases were fed into a central through-hole of the disk catalyst through an axial inlet port and flowed radially outward across the catalyst. Commercial ethanol (Samchun Chemical, 99%) and deionized water (15 MΩ) were used for the ATR reaction. All liquid fuels, including ethanol and water, were injected via isocratic pumps (Series II, Lab Alliance) into a vaporizer equipped with an electric heater. All gases were supplied using a mass flow controller (TSC-120, MKP). The reaction temperatures were controlled by an electric furnace. The operating conditions of the ATR and WGS reactions were tabulated in
Table
1
. The ATR reaction was conducted at an S/C of 2.5 and an O/C of 1. An S/C of >2.5 is required to prevent the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons such as acetaldehyde, ethylene, and ethane.
(10,39)
A higher S/C facilitates the subsequent WGS reaction, providing an opportunity to reduce the size of the CO clean-up unit.
(10)
Ethanol feeding rates were varied from 0.051 to 0.411 g/min, corresponding to GHSVs of 14,830–118,636 h
–1
. The reaction temperatures for ATR were varied from 600 to 750 °C. For testing the WGS reaction, a simulated gas was used (34.2 mol % H
2
O, 23.9 mol % H
2
, 27.3 mol % N
2
, 9.4 mol % CO
2
, and 5.1 mol % CO), the composition of which corresponds to that of the outlet gas of the Gibbs reactor operated at 750 °C where the inlet condition is ethanol with the S/C ratio of 2.5 and O/C of 1. The WGS reactions were conducted by modulating the reaction temperature from 350 to 500 °C and GHSV from 14,830 to 118,636 h
–1
.

div.p: Figure 2. Schematic diagram of the experimental setup for testing catalytic activity of the disk-type structured catalysts over ATR and WGS reactions.

div.div: Table 1. Ethanol Conversion and Gas Composition in ATR According to GHSV at 700 °C

div.h3: 2.4. Development and Operation of the ATR–WGS-Integrated Fuel Processor
div.div:
Based on the preliminary test data for the ATR and WGS reactions, and regarding the optimal volumes of the catalysts and operating temperatures to achieve the highest ethanol conversion with minimal CO content (see
Section 3.1
), an ATR–WGS-integrated fuel processor was developed, as shown in
Figure
3
a. The volumes of the fuel processor and the structured catalysts (ATR and WGS) were ca. 135 cm
3
and ca. 33 cm
3
, respectively. Note that the total processor volume does not include the additional space required for instrumentation, insulation, and piping. For a better understanding of the interior part of the fuel processor, a cut-way schematic is illustrated in
Figure
3
b. In the fuel processor, ATR and WGS reactors were integrated, and an internal heat exchanger was placed between the two reactors to sustain the temperature difference between the two reactors and to preheat the reactants of the ATR reactor. Fifteen layers of structured catalysts were stacked in both the ATR and WGS reactors and compressed firmly enough to close the gap between layers and ensure the channeling of the reacting gases. The reacting gas was further preheated in the outer surface of the ATR reactor and supplied to the inlet of the ATR reactor. The reactants flowed radially outward across the catalysts in the ATR reactor. The product gas from the ATR reactor was cooled down in the internal heat exchanger and supplied to the WGS reactor. The reactants flowed radially inward across the catalyst in the WGS reactor. Finally, the product gas exited the WGS reactor through an axial outlet port.

div.p: Figure 3. (a) Photograph, (b) cut-away schematic diagram, and (c) PFD of the ATR–WGS-integrated ethanol fuel processor. “HEX” means heat exchanger.

div.div:
A process flow diagram (PFD) of the entire ethanol fuel processor, along with an external heat exchanger to preheat the air and simultaneously cool the WGS outlet gas, is presented in
Figure
3
c. For the initial start-up of the reactor, an electrical heater was coiled around the ATR reactor. First, the air was preheated by the WGS outlet gas in the external heat exchanger and then mixed with ethanol and water. Subsequently, all reactants were heated by the ATR outlet gas at the internal heat exchanger and then fed into the ATR reactor. In the steady-state, the fuel processor was tested at an ethanol flow rate of 0.56 g/min with an S/C and O/C of 2.5 and 1.4, respectively. These operating conditions correspond to a thermal load of approximately 0.27 kW (power density ∼7.7 kW/L, LHV basis) and a space velocity of ∼20,000 h
–1
for each ATR and WGS reactor. The temperature of the fuel processor was monitored at four different positions, as depicted in
Figure
3
c. In this figure, TC1, TC2, TC3, and TC4 correspond to the inlet of the ATR reactor, the outlet of the WGS reactor, the surface of the fuel processor, and the outlet of the external heat exchanger, respectively.

div.h3: 2.5. Operation of HTPEMFCs using Reformate-Simulated Gases
div.div:
To determine whether the reformate gases from the fuel processor are utilizable in the HTPEMFCs, the behavior of the HTPEMFC single-cell fed by the ethanol-reformate-simulated gases was studied. Membrane electrode assemblies comprised of phosphoric acid doped polybenzimidazole membranes and electrodes with active areas of 25 cm
2
were used in the tests, following a previously reported preparation method and a testing procedure.
(40)
As listed in
Table
1
, four types of reformate-simulated gases were supplied to the anode side, which were simulated for the reformate gases with different CO concentrations (0.2–5.1 mol %, wet basis) from WGS reactors operating under different conditions. Gases 1–3 represented the outlet gases from the WGS reactor operated at 250, 400, and 500 °C, and gas 4 corresponded to the outlet gas from the ATR reactor operated at 750 °C. Specifically, gas 4 is the outlet gas with a thermodynamic equilibrium composition under the condition, wherein ethanol with an S/C of 2.5 and O/C of 1 is supplied to the Gibbs reactor operated at 750 °C. Gas 1, gas 2, and gas 3 are the outlet gases of the Gibbs reactor, while gas 4 is supplied to the inlet; formation of both methane and carbon was excluded from the Gibbs free energy minimization calculation. In the case of HTPEMFC, air was continuously supplied to the cathode side at a flow rate of 500 sccm throughout the entire test. Atmospheric pressures were maintained at the exits of both the anode and cathode.

The experimental procedure is described as follows. First, the operating temperature of the single-cell was raised to 180 °C, while pure H
2
with a total flow rate of 156 sccm was supplied to the anode. Subsequently, the cell performance was stabilized for 4 days at 0.5 V. After the stabilization process, the four reformate-simulated gases were successively fed into the anode. To incorporate 30 mol % H
2
O into the reformates, gaseous mixtures of H
2
, N
2
, CO
2
, and CO were previously supplied to a temperature-controlled humidifier. The single-cell temperature was changed from 180 to 150 °C. The cell current was recorded at 0.5 V for 2 h in each case after confirming the stabilization of the cell condition.

For gas analyses, the outlet gases were passed through a chiller at 5 °C to remove water vapor and then analyzed using an on-line gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890) equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors. N
2
, an inert gas, was used as an internal standard to quantify the other gases. The ethanol conversion of the ATR reaction and reforming efficiency are defined as given in
eqs 3
and
4
, where
3
is based on the carbon balance of all involved reactions: autothermal reaction of ethanol, ethanol decomposition, WGS reaction, methane SR, and CO methanation, as shown in
1
,
2
, and
5
–
8
, respectively.
(6)
(3)
(4)
(5)
(6)
(7)
(8)

The commercial software package Aspen Plus V7.1 was utilized for equilibrium calculations. For equilibrium analysis of the ATR reaction, H
2
, H
2
O, CO, CO
2
, CH
4
, C, O
2
, N
2
, and ethanol were taken into consideration in the isothermal Gibbs reactor. For the WGS reaction, two calculation processes were carried out. The first calculation, denoted equilibrium-1, included H
2
, H
2
O, CO, CO
2
, O
2
, and N
2
as constituents in the calculation, while CH
4
was added to the second calculation (denoted equilibrium-2).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 3.1. Catalytic Activity of the Catalyst in ATR and WGS
div.div:
We investigated the catalytic activities of the Rh/GDC-coated structured catalysts in the ATR and WGS reactions to obtain the optimal reaction temperatures and GHSVs for the design of the fuel processor.
Figure
4
represents the ethanol conversions in the ATR reaction with an S/C of 2.5 and O/C of 1.4 at different temperatures and GHSVs. The conditions which resulted in ethanol conversion of >99% were at a reaction temperature of >700 °C and GHSV of <88,977 h
–1
. Under these conditions, the gas compositions nearly converged to equilibrium values with a small amount of unreacted CH
4
(less than 1 mol %, dry basis), as listed in
Table
1
.

div.p:
Figure 4. Ethanol conversion in the ATR reaction according to GHSV: (■) 14,830 h
–1
, (red ●) 29,659 h
–1
, (green ▲) 59,318 h
–1
, (blue ▼) 88,977 h
–1
, and (pink ◀) 118,636 h
–1
. The dot-line represents equilibrium conversion calculated by Gibbs energy minimization.

div.div:
Using a reactant simulating the ATR outlet gas with ethanol conversion of 100% at 750 °C (H
2
O/H
2
/N
2
/CO
2
/CO = 34.2:23.9:27.3:9.4:5.1 mol %), the Rh/GDC-coated structured catalysts were further tested for their activity in the HTWGS reaction at 350–500 °C. As shown in
Figure
5
a, the CO concentration reached values ca. 2 mol % (H
2
O-free) at GHSV <29,659 h
–1
and temperatures of 400–450 °C. The considerable formation of methane, in amounts of up to 1.5 mol % (H
2
O-free), indicates the presence of methanation (
, Δ
H
298K
0
= −206 kJ/mol
–1
or
, Δ
H
298K
0
= −164 kJ/mol
–1
, ref
(41)
) alongside the WGS reaction (
Figure
5
b). Although the methanation reaction consumes a considerable amount of hydrogen, methanation is effective in decreasing the CO concentration beyond the thermodynamic limit determined by the WGS reaction only (equilibrium-1 vs equilibrium-2). From the activity tests for both ATR and WGS, it was concluded that the Rh/GDC-coated structured catalysts were sufficiently active in both the ATR and WGS reactions. Thermodynamic equilibrium was reached at certain GHSVs (ATR, <88,977 h
–1
; WGS, <29,659 h
–1
), which were achieved simply by dividing the reactor into two temperature zones, one with a temperature of >700 °C and the other at 400–450 °C. CO levels of close to 2 mol % (dry basis) were shown to only induce losses of active platinum of 10% in HTPEMFCs at 180 °C.
(13)

Figure 5. (a) CO and (b) CH
4
concentrations in the WGS reaction according to GHSV: (■) 14,830 h
–1
, (red ●) 29,659 h
–1
, (green ▲) 59,318 h
–1
, (blue ▼) 88,977 h
–1
, and (pink ◀) 118,636 h
–1
. The simulated gas (H
2
O/H
2
/N
2
/CO
2
/CO = 34.2:23.9:27.3:9.4:5.1 mol %) was used for the inlet gas. The solid-line and the dot-line represent equilibrium-1 (WGS reaction) and equilibrium-2 (WGS and methanation reactions), respectively.

div.h3: 3.2. Operation of the Ethanol ATR–WGS-Integrated Fuel Processor
div.div:
Based on the preliminary results described in the previous section, the ATR–WGS-integrated ethanol fuel processor was developed, as shown in
Figure
3
a,b. The start-up and thermal self-sustainability characteristics of the fuel processor were tested while it was wrapped with ceramic insulation.
Figure
6
shows the evolution of the reactor temperature during the start-up, which consisted of three distinct steps. First, the ATR reactor was heated using an electrical heater until the temperature of the surface of the WGS reactor reached 300 °C within 9 min [denoted as (a) in
Figure
6
], acquiring the temperature conditions required for the catalytic combustion of ethanol. Next, ethanol was supplied to the reactor along with oxygen in a complete combustion mode, and the flow rate of ethanol was gradually increased to 0.56 g/min, corresponding to a heat supply of 270 W [LHV basis; denoted as (b) in
Figure
6
]. Finally, the reaction conditions were changed from complete combustion mode to the ATR mode (ethanol feeding rate of 0.56 g/min; S/C 2.5; O/C 1–1.4) when the inlet temperature of the ATR reactor reached 700 °C [denoted as (c) in
Figure
6
]. It should be noted that the O/C was finally fixed at 1.4, which is higher than that used in the preliminary catalytic test (O/C = 1), for thermal self-sustainability of the ATR reactor above 700 °C.

div.p: Figure 6. Temperature profiles in the integrated reactor during the start-up protocol: (■) inlet of the ATR reactor, (red ●) outlet of the WGS reactor, and (green ▲) surface of the WGS reactor. The start-up protocol consists of three steps: (a) heating with an electrical heater, (b) stoichiometric combustion of ethanol and oxygen with a heat supply of 270 W (LHV basis), and (c) transition to the ATR condition (EtOH feeding rate, 0.56 g/min; S/C, 2.5; O/C, 1.4).

div.div:
After start-up, the integrated reactor was continuously operated over 700 h to produce hydrogen at rates of 600–700 sccm. The evolution of reforming efficiency and gas composition (H
2
-free basis) during the operation are depicted in
Figure
7
a. Hydrogen production by the ethanol fuel processor was stable during continuous operation, with some fluctuations. The reforming efficiency gradually decreased from 46.5 to 42.2% due to the increase in methane concentration from 1.4 to 2.5 mol % (dry basis), that is, the decreased in hydrogen selectivity.

div.p:
Figure 7. (a) Product composition and fuel conversion for 700 h operation; O/C = 1.4, S/C = 2.5: (■) H
2
, (red ●) N
2
, (green ▲) CH
4
, (blue ▼) CO, and (pink ◀) CO
2
. (◇) reforming efficiency. (b) Temperature profile in the desulfurization catalyst for 700 h operation: (■) inlet of the ATR reactor, (red ●) outlet of the WGS reactor, and (green ▲) outlet of the external heat exchanger.

div.div:
Table
2
presents the molar concentrations, hydrogen production, reforming efficiency, and ethanol conversion at 20 and 700 h. The CO concentration in the WGS outlet was maintained in the range of 2.4–2.7 mol % (dry basis).
Figure
7
b shows the temperatures of the inlet of the ATR reactor, the outlet of the WGS reactor, and the outlet of the external heat exchanger. The inlet temperature of the ATR reactor was maintained at ca. 750 °C, which was optimal for the ATR reaction. The 200 °C outlet gas from the external heat exchanger, where the air was heated by the WGS outlet gas, was suitable for supply to the HTPEMFC operating in the range of 150–180 °C, considering the possible heat losses of the reformate in the pipelines leading to the HTPEMFC stack. Although the outlet temperature of the WGS reactor was measured to be ∼270 °C, the actual gas temperature was seemingly higher. It is worthy to note that there was a considerable heat transfer length between the core of the WGS reactor and the thermocouple, which may have resulted in temperature differences of >100 °C. The CO concentration of the reformate gas of 2.4–2.7 mol % again confirmed that the temperature inside the WGS reactor was 400–450 °C, which is similar to that at which the outlet gas from the Gibbs reactor is operated (ca. 520 °C). It was concluded that the successful demonstration of the ethanol fuel processor was related to the unique configuration of the annular-type ATR–WGS-integrated reactor and the insertion of an internal heat exchanger between the two annular-type reactors. This heat exchanger, where the outlet gas from the ATR was cooled by the air from the external heat exchanger at a temperature below 200 °C, successfully allowed the fuel processor to operate with two distinct temperature zones.
Table 2. Performance of the Integrated Ethanol Fuel Processor at 20 and 700 h

div.h3: 3.3. Next Steps to Improve the Performance of the Ethanol Fuel Processor
div.div:
Despite the promising results, there is room for improvement in the structured catalyst to further increase the reforming efficiency by enhancing its selectivity for H
2
. Although Rh-based catalysts exhibit good activity in the ethanol ATR and WGS reactions, it is necessary to find alternatives to Rh, considering that Rh is a rare and extremely high-priced metal and that the methanation side-reaction occurs significantly alongside the WGS reaction when using Rh-based catalysts. Suppressing methanation is especially important because 3–4 mol of H
2
is consumed to produce every mole of CH
4
(see above). Ru, which has been reported to be a less-expensive alternative which still exhibits high activity in ethanol reforming,
(19,39)
and Pt, which exhibits the lowest methanation activity among Ru, Rh, Ni, and Pd,
(23)
would be better choices in the ATR and WGS reactors, respectively. In addition, the hot-spot formation in the structured catalyst on the front side of the ATR reactor should be alleviated to ensure the long-term stability of the fuel processor.

The steady operation of the integrated fuel processor over 700 h suggested that there was no noticeable deactivation of the catalyst during the operation. Postmortem analyses, however, showed significant corrosion of the structured catalysts near the inlet of the ATR reactor (
Figure S1
), which was seemingly due to the concentrated combustion and consequent hot-spot formation. Although the maximum temperature in the ATR reactor was not detected by the thermocouple, it is plausible that the peak catalyst temperature reached over 1000 °C, considering that corrosion due to excessive oxidation of the FeCrAlloy can occur at temperatures higher than 1200 °C. One of the simplest approaches to alleviating hot-spot formation in the structured catalyst is to set the S/C slightly higher to increase endothermicity. The second solution involves initiating fuel combustion slightly away from the reactor, at porous refractory materials such as Al
2
O
3
and SiC foams, which can endure temperatures of up to 1600 °C.
(42)
Another problem with this fuel processor was the use of excessive air (O/C = 1.4) to maintain the ATR inlet temperature above 700 °C; the O/C value should be diminished to improve the efficiency of the reformer. Heat loss can be alleviated by enhancing insulation. The fuel processor was herein covered by a ceramic insulating material (Cerablanket 1260, Thermal Ceramics), which could be replaced by an air jacket to absorb the heat lost externally or by introducing vacuum packing with radiation shielding to minimize heat loss.
(43)

The CO concentration in the reformate should also be lowered by utilizing an additional low-temperature shift reactor to render more flexibility in the operational temperature for HTPEMFCs. The CO concentration of the reformate in this study was ∼2.4 mol % (dry basis) and ∼1.0 mol % (wet basis). A higher operating temperature would be favorable for increasing the CO tolerance of the HTPEMFC.
Figure S2
shows the performance of the HTPEMFC single cell for different operational temperatures and anode gases with different compositions. Assuming that the HTPEMFC single cell should operate at a current greater than 0.08 A/cm
2
, the single-cell running on gas 1 with a CO concentration of 0.2 mol % (wet basis) can be operated at temperatures from 154 °C. However, when the single cell was operated on a different gas such as gas 2 (CO concentration 1.0 mol %, wet basis) or gas 3 (CO concentration 2.1 mol %, wet basis), the lowest viable operational temperatures of the HTPEMFC single-cell increased to 168 and 175 °C, respectively. HTPEMFC stacks often suffer from internal temperature fluctuations that are more serious than those encountered in the single-cell case. It is beneficial for the HTPEMFC stack to utilize fuel with a lower CO concentration, as this enables a wider operational temperature range. By adopting additional LTWGS reactors operating at lower temperatures (ca. 250 °C), the CO concentration can be lowered at CO concentrations of ca. 0.2 mol % (wet basis).

Last but not least, for the successful commercialization of the as-developed H
2
supply solution, the bioethanol fuel processor needs to tackle additional challenges by (i) lessening warm-up time for ATR by optimizing ATR operating conditions and lowering thermal mass,
(44)
(ii) lowering the system complexity
(12)
through the optimization of the sizing and configuration of the constituents of the fuel processor,
(45)
and (iii) enhancing the load-following capability. By mitigating the issues as-mentioned above, we highly anticipate that the bioethanol fuel processor can be soon deployed to the market to extend H
2
-storage limits or function as an auxiliary power unit based on bioethanol with a lower cost and reduced safety risk.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we developed a 126 W (LHV basis) bioethanol fuel processor with an all-in-one design, combining the ATR and WGS reactors and an internal heat exchanger. The fuel processor achieved a hydrogen generation rate of 30 sccm H
2
/mL
reactor
, as well as ethanol conversion of >90% and CO concentration of 2.4–2.7 mol % (dry basis), over 700 h long-term operation. The above-mentioned hydrogen generation rate was equivalent to 2.3 kW
e
/L
reactor
, given that a hydrogen consumption rate at the max output of a commercial 1 kW
e
polymer electrolyte stack is ca. 13 slm. The quality of the reformed gas was suitable for being supplied to the HTPEMFC. With further improvements to the aforementioned drawbacks, and with scale-up efforts and continued interest in bioethanol as a greener and more sustainable energy carrier, it is believed that the findings of this study could lead to competitive hydrogen production solutions in the mobile and transport sectors. The as-developed bioethanol fuel processor could be adapted for other hydrogen production systems based on liquid organic hydrogen carriers with high operating temperatures.

Recent advancements in sustainable transportation led to the release of com. available fuel cell elec. vehicles (FCEVs). Examples such as the Toyota Mirai and the Hyundai Tucson are the culmination of many years of research and development. FCEVs provide a scalable pathway for clean H fuel to be used for transportation power generation. The following work presents modeling and anal. on the topic of com. medium and heavy duty (MD and HD) vehicles that are operated using H fuel cells. This work studies how H fuel could be stored onboard MD/HD vehicles, and how these vehicles perform under various drive cycles that simulate real driving conditions for various vehicle classes and occupations. The aim is to provide an anal. framework to build increased understanding for which MD/HD vehicle wt. classes and vocations could provide economic and environmental benefits when using H fuel cell technologies.

A review. The demand for clean power source which can be used to run the various types of vehicles on the road is increasing on a daily basis due to the fact that high emissions released from internal combustion engine play a significant role in air pollution and climate change. Fuel cell devices, particularly Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) type, are strong candidates to replace the internal combustion engines in the transport industry. The PEMFC technol. still has many challenges including high cost, low durability and hydrogen storage problems which limit the wide-world commercialization of this technol. In this paper, the fuel cell cost, durability and performances challenges which are assocd. with using of fuel cell technol. for transport applications are detailed and reviewed. Recent developments that deal with the proposed challenges are reported. Furthermore, problems of hydrogen infrastructure and hydrogen storage in the fuel cell vehicle are discussed.

Yet growing enough corn to produce even a small fraction of the amt. required for vehicles in the U.S. will be a drain on precious resources, including H2O and land. Further, widespread agricultural prodn. will decrease the quality of H2O and accelerate harmful environmental changes such as the hypoxic zone in the Gulf of Mexico. Due to increasing population and industrialization, the demand of energy is increasing day by day. Simultaneously, the worldwide bio-ethanol prodn. is increasing constantly. The maize, sugarcane and sugar beets are major traditional agricultural crops used as bio-ethanol prodn. but these crops are unable to meet the global demand of bio-ethanol prodn. due to their primary value of food and feed. Hence, cellulosic materials such as agro-residues are attractive feedstock for bio-ethanol prodn. The cellulosic material is the most abundant biomass and agro-residues on the earth. Bio-ethanol from agro-residues could be a promising technol. that involves four processes of pre-treatment, enzymic hydrolysis, fermn. and distn. These processes have several challenges and limitations such as biomass transport and handling, and efficient pre-treatment process for removing the lignin from the lignocellulosic agro-residues. Proper pre-treatment process may increase the concns. of fermentable sugars after enzymic hydrolysis, thereby improving the efficiency of the whole process. Others, efficient microbes and genetically modified microbes may also enhance the enzymic hydrolysis. Conversion of cellulose to ethanol requires some new pre-treatment, enzymic and fermn. technologies, to make the whole process cost effective. In this review, we have discussed about current technologies for sustainable bioethanol prodn. from agro-residues.

Ethanol steam reforming with pure ethanol and com. bioethanol (S/C = 3) was carried out inside the housing of the exhaust gas pipe of a gasoline internal combustion engine (ICE) by using exhaust heat (610-620 °C). Various catalytic honeycombs loaded with potassium-promoted cobalt hydrotalcite and with ceria-based rhodium-palladium catalysts were tested under different reactant loads. The hydrogen yield obtained over the cobalt-based catalytic honeycomb at low load (F/W < 25 mLliq·g-1cat·h-1, GHSV = 4·102 h-1) was remarkably high, whereas that obtained over the noble metal-based catalytic honeycombs was much superior at high loads (F/W = 25-150 mLliq·g-1cat·h-1, GHSV = 4·102-2.4·103 h-1). At higher reactant loads the overall hydrogen prodn. was limited by heat transfer from the exhaust heat to the reformer inside the housing of the exhaust gas pipe of the ICE. Extensive carbon deposition occurred over the cobalt-based honeycomb, making its use impractical. In contrast, stability runs (>200 h) at high load (F/W = 150 mLliq·g-1cat·h-1, GHSV = 2.4·103 h-1) showed that promotion of the ceria-supported noble metal catalyst with alumina and zirconia is a key element for practical application using com. bioethanol. HRTEM anal. of post mortem honeycombs loaded with RhPd/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2-Al2O3 showed no carbon formation and no metal agglomeration.

Several reactions can contributed to the overall process of exhaust gas reforming, during which some of the engine fuel is catalytically converted mainly to H2 and CO. If the predominant reactions are endothermic, the process acts as a means of exhaust-heat recovery, and the fuel heating value is raised. When using conventional gasoline or diesel fuel, the reforming catalyst is required to promote steam-and dry-reforming, at the expense of the exothermic reactions-water gas shift, methanation, partial oxidn. and combustion. In this study we show that a precious metal formulation is capable of catalyzing most of the key reforming routes with the exception of the water gas shift reaction, under the set of conditions that we have used to simulate an exhaust from a bioethanol-fulled spark ignition engine. Our results predict that the overall process of exhaust gas reforming of C2H5OH will be oxidative, and yet waste heat will be consumed. The expected increase in fuel heating value is 6%, but can rise towards 20% if there is less O2 available in the exhaust, allowing more of the bioethanol to react by steam- and dry-reforming in the catalyst bed. By feeding the reformate back to the engine, the intention is to improve the fuel economy and emission quality.

This paper describes the design, manufg., operation, and optimization of a mobile ethanol reformer fuel cell system for off-grid power prodn. The reformer system includes an autothermal reformer, high and low temp. shift reactors, a selective methanation reactor, and a tail gas combustor. A min. amt. of process controls and little internal heat integration kept system architecture simple. Process simulations provided optimal operating parameters, expected hydrogen yield, and system efficiency. The reformer temp. was selected to be 730 °C with minimal methane prodn. and no soot formation in the reactor. The oxygen-to-steam ratio is detd. by the temp. of feed streams, reforming temp. and heat losses. It was set to be in the order of 0.9. The steam-to-carbon ratio has no impact on carbon monoxide concn. (on a dry basis) in the reformer system product gas, i.e. at the outlet of the selective methanation reactor. Therefore, it was selected to be 2.5, sufficiently high to avoid soot formation in the reforming reactor and yet small enough to keep the size of the water evaporator in a sensible range. The reformer fuel cell system was operated in a lab environment and all reactors were thoroughly investigated. Main focus was to keep the carbon monoxide concn. at the outlet of the selective methanation reactor below 10 ppmv at all times. Furthermore, start-up and shut down procedures were optimized to minimize degrdn. of the catalysts. Finally, the complete reformer fuel cell system was operated to investigate its performance. System controls allowed fully automated operation of the integrated reformer fuel cell system.

Power required to run auxiliary systems on a passenger car, such as those for air conditioning and advanced vehicle control, reduces the driving range of a vehicle equipped with a hybrid drive train. Under practical driving conditions, a significant amt. of addnl. energy is required at low power levels compared to the rated power of the drive unit. In the present study, a fuel cell-battery drive train augmented by an on-board fuel (ethanol) processor to provide the motoring power requirements of a car is considered. Using systematic driving cycle simulations that take account of power-to-wt., energy-to-wt. and power-to-efficiency factors of on-board power sources under simulated load conditions, it is shown that a combination of steadily-operated compact ethanol reformer, a low-power battery continuously charged by excess reformer capacity and a high-power fuel cell powered by conservatively-used hydrogen from cylinder can increase the range of hybrid fuel cell drivetrains to about 750 km. Although the overall energy consumption of the three-way hybrid is more than that of fuel cell-battery hybrid, lesser use of stored hydrogen improves the fuel economy of the hybrid drivetrain. While the system complexity is increased, long-range distressed mode operation becomes feasible with the added fuel processor.

We exptl. studied a high temp. proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell to investigate the effects of CO poisoning at different temps. The effects of temp., for various percentages of CO mixed with anode hydrogen stream, on the current-voltage characteristics of the fuel cell are investigated. The results show that at low temp., the fuel cell performance degraded significantly with higher CO percentage (i.e., 5% CO) in the anode hydrogen stream compared to the high temp. A detailed electrochem. anal. regarding CO coverage on electrode surface is presented which indicates that electrochem. oxidn. is favorable at high temp. A cell diagnostic test shows that both 2% CO and 5% CO can be tolerated equally at low c.d. (<0.3 A cm-2) with high cell voltage (>0.5 V) at 180 °C without any cell performance loss. At high temp., both 2% CO and 5% CO can be tolerated at higher c.d. (>0.5 A cm-2) with moderate cell voltage (0.2-0.5 V) when the cell voltage loss within 0.03-0.05 V would be acceptable. The surface coverage of platinum catalyst by CO at low temp. is very high compared to high temp. Results suggest that the PEM fuel cell operating at 180 °C or above, the reformate gas with higher CO percentage (i.e., 2-5%) can be fed to the cell directly from the fuel processor.

The current status on the understanding of the various operational aspects of high temp. proton exchange membrane fuel cells (HT-PEMFC) has been summarized. The paper focuses on phosphoric acid-doped polybenzimidazole (PBI)-based HT-PEMFCs and an overview of the common practices of their design and characterization techniques at single cell, stack and system levels is given. The state-of-the-art concepts of different degrdn. mechanisms and methods of their mitigation are also discussed. Moreover, accelerated stress testing (AST) procedures for HT-PEMFCs available in literature are outlined. Catalyst degrdn. and electrolyte loss take place at higher rates in the beginning of life of the fuel cell. This is due to the smaller size of Pt particles and the presence of excess phosphoric acid in the beginning of life that favor the resp. degrdn. Therefore, the redistribution of phosphoric acid in the membrane and the electrodes is crucial for the proper activation of the fuel cell, and a startup procedure should take this into account in order to avoid beginning of life degrdn. Online monitoring of the fuel cell system's state of health using diagnostic tools can help detect fuel cell faults for targeted interventions based on the obsd. conditions to prevent sudden failures and to prolong the fuel cell's lifetime. However, the technol. is still under development and robust online diagnostics tools are hardly available. Currently, mitigation is mainly done based on favorable operating conditions and techniques to recover degrdn. and the development of more resistant components that can withstand the known degrdn. mechanisms.

A review on steam reforming of ethanol for prodn. of hydrogen for fuel cells. Process engineering aspects of ethanol steam reforming are discussed. High temps., low pressures and high water-to-ethanol ratios in the feed favor hydrogen prodn. Ni, Co, Ni/Cu, and noble metal (Pd, Pt, Rh) supported catalysts are promising. Major concerns are fast catalyst coking and formation of byproducts such as methane, di-Et ether, and acetaldehyde. To overcome these problems, the process should be carried out in a two-layer fixed bed catalytic reactor; first, ethanol should be dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde in presence of Cu-based catalyst at 573-673 K and then this stream should be passed over a bed contg. a mixt. of Ni-based catalyst and a chemisorbent at low temps. of ∼723 K. The entire process of ethanol steam reforming coupled with selective CO2 removal by chemisorption will enable prodn. of high-purity H2 and hence is very promising.

The authors compare the auto-thermal partial oxidn. of 1-propanol and 2-propanol with methanol and ethanol on Rh with several additives in short-contact time reactors. All alcs. could produce H2 at 70-90% selectivity, and Rh-Ce was superior to Rh in producing H2. Methanol produced high conversion and high selectivity to H2 even at high C/O where temps. fell to <600°C. 2-Propanol gave lower conversions and less H2 and CO than the other alcs., but produced the most chems. Above C/O = 1.5, ∼ 70% of 2-propanol was converted into acetone or propylene. Up to 20% propylene was formed at C/O = 1.5. But 1-propanol gave <8% propylene and <15% propanal at any C/O and produced more ethylene than propylene. Much more oxygenates and olefins were formed on Rh than on Rh-Ce. Different alcs. have very different selectivity in catalytic partial oxidn. at short contact times even at high temps. Rapid adsorption of alcs. as alkoxy species leads to complete dissocn. to H2 and CO. Probably acetone and olefins likely were produced primarily by homogeneous reactions after all O2 were consumed in the catalyst. Ethanol is a renewable, portable, and non-toxic liq. that is a possible source of hydrogen for PEM fuel cells. This work describes an auto-thermal flat plate catalytic wall reactor for steam reforming of ethanol into H2 and CO2. Catalytic methane combustion on Pt is coupled to ethanol steam reforming on Rh and Rh-Ce across an auto-thermal wall. At a steam/carbon ratio of 3/1 the reactor gave >99% conversion of ethanol. An H2/CO ratio of 3/1 was obtained at a residence time of ∼100 ms and an upstream temp. of ∼800 °C. Methane selectivities of less than 1% were obtained with Rh-Ce. Water-gas shift was also considered in order to increase the H2/CO ratio. The reactor was lengthened to include a cooler water-gas shift section using a Pt-Ce catalyst. The extended reactor produced >99% conversion of ethanol and an H2/CO ratio of 30/1 at a steam/carbon ratio of 4/1. The residence time was ∼400 ms, and the upstream temp. was ∼900 °C in the extended reactor. The reactor was stable for at least 100 h with no detectable degrdn. in performance.

Reactor performance during doping and regeneration was used to analyze effects of inorgs. on the Rh catalyst and to test the ability for regeneration. Of these elements, K-, P-, and Mg-doped ethanol operated autothermally over the 6 h test period, whereas Si, S, Na, and Ca quenched the reaction. The ability of the catalyst to be regenerated after doping was investigated by switching to inorg.-free fuel. Regeneration was possible for each of the inorgs. studied. Silicon shut down autothermal operation the fastest, but complete regeneration of the catalyst was achieved by passing pure ethanol. Sulfur caused extensive coke formation and disintegration of the α-Al2O3 support. Phosphorus increased ethanol dehydration to ethylene, indicating acid chem., which was observable even upon regeneration. Sodium and potassium increased acetaldehyde selectivities because of their basic nature. Calcium and magnesium accumulated at the front face of the catalyst, forming CaCO3 and MgO, resp. No liq. slag formation was obsd. with any of the inorgs.

We have examd. the water-gas-shift reaction over noble metals and metals with ceria for catalyst contact times between 0.008 and 0.05 s for temps. from 300 to 1000 °C. With reactants of CO, H2, and H2O at a 1/2/4 compn., the reaction approached equil. at these contact times for temps. as low as 380 °C, which corresponds to a 50/1 H2/CO ratio. All results follow the equil. conversion vs. temp. curve at high temps. and then the rate decreases rapidly as temp. decreases. All metals show considerable promotion upon ceria addn., with Pt/ceria showing the most promise in terms of promotion, stability, and lack of methanation activity. A simple kinetic model that assumes first-order reversible reaction in all species fits all data at all temps. from equil. to low conversions. The rate is nearly independent of surface area over a wide variation of parameters, and rates indicate that mass-transfer limitations are not dominant.

Fuel processing systems that are used in conjunction with polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cells require high activity water gas shift (WGS) catalysts that remove carbon monoxide, a poison for membranes in the fuel cell stacks. WGS activity of various noble metals supported on cubic, nanocryst., high surface area, large pore ceria-zirconia was measured at a space velocity of 312,000 h-1, under two feed gas compns. that simulated the high temp. shift (HTS) and the low temp. shift (LTS) conditions found in a typical fuel processing system. The (HTS) feed compn. was 4.9% CO, 10.5% CO2, 33% H2O, 30.3% H2; and the low temp. gas compn. (LTS) was 1.5% CO, 5% CO2, 45% H2O, 25% H2, with the balance of the stream being N2 in both cases. The activity trend under both feed gases over a broad range of temps. (200°-320°) was Pt > Rh > Ru ∼ Pd > Ir > Au. This trend did not agree with those previously reported in literature or with CO uptake data for these samples. We hypothesize that this reflects the dominance of different reaction mechanisms under different gas compns. and temps. The discrepancy in the activities obsd. in this study and those reported in literature might also be attributed to differences in the synthesis techniques of the oxide supports and metal loading. Our study also found that the turnover rate (TOR) for the Pt catalyst was maximized in the range between 1-2% loading under both HTS and LTS conditions.

The av. structure and the local structure of nanocryst. Rh-doped CeO2 catalysts, prepd. using a co-pptn. method, were studied using a set of structural (PDF, HRTEM, XRD) and spectral (XPS, Raman spectroscopy) methods. The samples with Rh content <10%, calcined at 450°, were homogeneous solid solns. A comparison of the exptl. results and pair distribution function (PDF) modeling data showed that Rh3+ substitutes Ce4+ ions in the fluorite phase. Charge equil. is obtained by the O vacancy for each Rh3+ cation introduced into the ceria cell. The solid soln. demonstrated high catalytic activity in low-temp. CO oxidn. (LTO CO). The solid solns. were stable only in a nanocryst. state and decompd. upon thermal treatment. The calcination of the solid soln. at T > 450° results in a decrease in the catalytic activity that is accompanied by Rh assocn. in the subsurface area and strong distortion of the anionic subcell. At T = 800° α-Rh2O3 nanoparticles are formed on the surface of the fluorite phase. The XRD-detectable Rh oxide phases are formed after calcination at 1000°. Some parts of Rh within the subsurface RhxCe1-xO2-δ solid soln. remain and they preserve catalytic properties for low-temp. oxidn.

This work describes the development of a compact ethanol fuel processor for small scale high temp. polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (HT-PEMFC) systems with 200-500 W elec. power output. Promising markets for reformer fuel cell systems based on ethanol are mobile or portable leisure and security power supply applications as well as small scale stationary off grid power supply and backup power. Main components of the fuel processor to be developed were the reformer reactor, the shift converter, a catalytic burner and heat exchangers. Development focused in particular on the homogeneous evapn. of the liq. reactants ethanol and water for the reformer and burner and on the development of an efficient start-up method, resp. Theor. as well as exptl. work has been carried out for all main components sep. including for example catalyst screening and evaporator performance tests in a first project period. Afterwards all components have been assembled to a complete fuel processor which has been qualified with various operation parameter set-ups. A theor. defined basic operation point could practically be confirmed. The overall start-up time to receive reformate gas with appropriate quality to feed an HT-PEMFC (xCO < 2%) takes around 30 min. At steady state operation the hydrogen power output is around 900 W with H2 and CO fractions of 41.2% and 1.5%, resp.

In recent years, hydrogen prodn. from renewable feed-stocks attracts particular attention. Specifically, the steam reforming of biomass-derived bioethanol could provide H2-rich effluent streams, representing an interesting research field. This study focuses on the development of bimetallic structured catalysts (contg. Ni and Pt as active species and supported on ceria and ceria-zirconia) active in Ethanol Steam Reforming (ESR) reaction at low-temp. (300-600 °C) and characterized by improved heat transfer properties. ESR reaction was carried out on ceramic foams and, as a comparison, on powders catalysts. In particular, catalytic tests were carried out on two reactor configurations: catalytic powders were tested in both a tubular and annular reactor; in addn., the tubular configuration was also employed for the structured catalysts. Unsatisfactory results were obsd. for powders in the tubular reactor while the better thermal management of the annular configuration ensured significantly higher conversions. Moreover, the enhanced thermal cond. of SiC foams catalysts, tested in the tubular reactor, allowed overcoming heat transfer limitations in an easy reactor geometry, resulting in very good performances. The catalytic behavior of bimetallic CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 based catalysts was also compared and the effect of catalytic support on ethanol conversion and H2 yield at different space velocities (100,000-400,000 h-1) was investigated. Finally, Pt-Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts, which displayed a more interesting catalytic activity with respect to CeO2 based samples, were employed for stability tests at 100,000 h-1 and 450 °C: products gas distribution was not affected during TOS and total ethanol conversion was recorded for almost 5 h.

Oxidative steam reforming of methanol is shown to produce extremely high hydrogen yield. Specific hydrogen prodn. rates as high as 425 kWt/L of reactor vol. were demonstrated in a novel Microlith-based catalytic reactor. At reduced space velocities hydrogen concn. in the reformate stream was as high as 50%, while CO concn. was as low as 1.2%. The thermal efficiency of the oxidative steam reforming process is >80%. It is shown that the autothermal oxidative steam reforming process consists of three reactions: methanol oxidn., methanol decompn., and water gas shift. These reactions have different kinetic rates and progress in an overlapping sequence along the catalyst bed. This allows a flat temp. profile and approach to equil. product compn. to be achieved in a single catalyst bed.

A review. Bio-ethanol is a prosperous renewable energy carrier mainly produced from biomass fermn. Reforming of bio-ethanol provides a promising method for hydrogen prodn. from renewable resources. Besides operating conditions, the use of catalysts plays a crucial role in hydrogen prodn. through ethanol reforming. Rh and Ni are so far the best and the most commonly used catalysts for ethanol steam reforming towards hydrogen prodn. The selection of proper support for catalyst and the methods of catalyst prepn. significantly affect the activity of catalysts. In terms of hydrogen prodn. and long-term stability, MgO, ZnO, CeO2, and La2O3 are suitable supports for Rh and Ni due to their basic characteristics, which favor ethanol dehydrogenation but inhibit dehydration. As Rh and Ni are inactive for water gas shift reaction (WGSR), the development of bimetallic catalysts, alloy catalysts, and double-bed reactors is promising to enhance hydrogen prodn. and long-term catalyst stability. Autothermal reforming of bio-ethanol has the advantages of lesser external heat input and long-term stability. Its overall efficiency needs to be further enhanced, as part of the ethanol feedstock is used to provide low-grade thermal energy. Development of millisecond-contact time reactor provides a low-cost and effective way to reform bio-ethanol and hydrocarbons for fuel upgrading. Despite its early R&D stage, bio-ethanol reforming for hydrogen prodn. shows promises for its future fuel cell applications.

Deposition of γ-Al2O3 washcoats onto Al and FeCrAlloy supports in the form of slabs and onto α-Al2O3 tubes was performed according to a two-step procedure involving: (a) deposition of a boehmite primer, and (b) deposition of the γ-Al2O3 layer, both by dip coating into powder dispersions in HNO3 aq. solns. We present herein data concerning the effects of the major prepn. variables (HNO3 and H2O concns. in the dispersion, withdrawal velocity, drying temp., no. of dipping cycles, calcination temp.) on the deposited coating load and on the adherence of the washcoat. Based on a rheol. characterization of the γ-Al2O3 dispersions, we propose also a correlation between their apparent viscosity and the washcoat load. A series of Ru catalysts supported on cordierite monoliths, ceramic foams and γ-Al2O3 pellets was prepd. and tested for the prodn. of hydrogen by catalytic partial oxidn. of ethanol. The catalyst supported on a cordierite monolith exhibited excellent catalytic performance for a wide variety of process conditions and excellent long-term stability with low coke formation. The effect of the steam/ethanol molar ratio on conversion and selectivity was relatively small. A more pronounced effect was obsd. for the oxygen/ethanol ratio. Overall, the catalysts on all three supports were able to convert ethanol completely with high selectivity towards the desired products. The Ru supported on a ceramic foam catalyst provided comparatively better performance, probably due to the smaller pore sizes and higher tortuosity of this support.

Acid-doped polybenzimidazole (PBI) membrane and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-based electrodes are used for the membrane electrode assembly (MEA) in high-temp. polymer electrolyte fuel cells (HTPEFCs). To find the optimum PTFE content for the catalyst layer, the PTFE ratio in the electrodes is varied from 25 to 50%. To improve the performance of the electrodes, PBI is added to the catalyst layer. With a wt. ratio of PTFE to Pt/C of 45:55 (45% PTFE in the catalyst layer), the fuel cell shows good performance at 150° under non-humidified conditions. When 5% PBI is added to the electrodes, performance is further improved (250 mA/cm2 at 0.6 V). The 20 W class HTPEFC stack is fabricated with a novel MEA. This MEA consists of 8 layers (1 H3PO4-doped PBI membrane, 2 electrodes, 1 sub-gasket, 2 gas-diffusion media, 2 gas-sealing gaskets). The sub-gasket mitigates the destruction of a highly acid-doped PBI membrane and provides long-term durability to the fuel cell stack. The stack operated for 1200 h without noticeable cell degrdn.

The thermal partial oxidn. process of methane was studied numerically and exptl. Thermodn. calcns. and kinetic simulation were performed using CHEMKIN tools to det. the practical operating conditions. Exptl., a porous material-based reactor was built to perform the partial oxidn. process. Temp. profiles along the reactor central axis and concn. profiles of CO, H2, CO2, C2H2 and CH4 were measured. Two different porous structures were installed in the reaction zone: Al2O3 fiber static mixer structures and SiC foams. The effects of air preheating temp., thermal load and air ratio on the reforming process were studied for both structures. The numerical calcn. showed that an air ratio down to 0.4 is a practical limit to perform the partial oxidn. process. Exptl., the air preheating temp. has no significant influence on the syngas compn.; however, it does affect the soot point (λ c). Higher heat recuperation was detected in the case of SiC foam based reformer than in the case of the Al2O3 mixer one. The SiC foam based reactor showed also a better performance than the Al2O3 regarding the soot point. For air preheating temp. of 700°, the current soot point for the SiC foam based reformer was 0.42, while it was 0.45 for the Al2O3 mixer one.

Recent advancements in sustainable transportation led to the release of com. available fuel cell elec. vehicles (FCEVs). Examples such as the Toyota Mirai and the Hyundai Tucson are the culmination of many years of research and development. FCEVs provide a scalable pathway for clean H fuel to be used for transportation power generation. The following work presents modeling and anal. on the topic of com. medium and heavy duty (MD and HD) vehicles that are operated using H fuel cells. This work studies how H fuel could be stored onboard MD/HD vehicles, and how these vehicles perform under various drive cycles that simulate real driving conditions for various vehicle classes and occupations. The aim is to provide an anal. framework to build increased understanding for which MD/HD vehicle wt. classes and vocations could provide economic and environmental benefits when using H fuel cell technologies.

A review. The demand for clean power source which can be used to run the various types of vehicles on the road is increasing on a daily basis due to the fact that high emissions released from internal combustion engine play a significant role in air pollution and climate change. Fuel cell devices, particularly Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) type, are strong candidates to replace the internal combustion engines in the transport industry. The PEMFC technol. still has many challenges including high cost, low durability and hydrogen storage problems which limit the wide-world commercialization of this technol. In this paper, the fuel cell cost, durability and performances challenges which are assocd. with using of fuel cell technol. for transport applications are detailed and reviewed. Recent developments that deal with the proposed challenges are reported. Furthermore, problems of hydrogen infrastructure and hydrogen storage in the fuel cell vehicle are discussed.

A review. EtOH made from corn was politically held up in the U.S. as a soln. to dependency on petrochem. fuel. Yet growing enough corn to produce even a small fraction of the amt. required for vehicles in the U.S. will be a drain on precious resources, including H2O and land. Further, widespread agricultural prodn. will decrease the quality of H2O and accelerate harmful environmental changes such as the hypoxic zone in the Gulf of Mexico. Biofuels can decrease reliance on fossil fuels, but their prodn. needs to be made sustainable so as to avoid myriad false promises.

Due to increasing population and industrialization, the demand of energy is increasing day by day. Simultaneously, the worldwide bio-ethanol prodn. is increasing constantly. The maize, sugarcane and sugar beets are major traditional agricultural crops used as bio-ethanol prodn. but these crops are unable to meet the global demand of bio-ethanol prodn. due to their primary value of food and feed. Hence, cellulosic materials such as agro-residues are attractive feedstock for bio-ethanol prodn. The cellulosic material is the most abundant biomass and agro-residues on the earth. Bio-ethanol from agro-residues could be a promising technol. that involves four processes of pre-treatment, enzymic hydrolysis, fermn. and distn. These processes have several challenges and limitations such as biomass transport and handling, and efficient pre-treatment process for removing the lignin from the lignocellulosic agro-residues. Proper pre-treatment process may increase the concns. of fermentable sugars after enzymic hydrolysis, thereby improving the efficiency of the whole process. Others, efficient microbes and genetically modified microbes may also enhance the enzymic hydrolysis. Conversion of cellulose to ethanol requires some new pre-treatment, enzymic and fermn. technologies, to make the whole process cost effective. In this review, we have discussed about current technologies for sustainable bioethanol prodn. from agro-residues.

Ethanol steam reforming with pure ethanol and com. bioethanol (S/C = 3) was carried out inside the housing of the exhaust gas pipe of a gasoline internal combustion engine (ICE) by using exhaust heat (610-620 °C). Various catalytic honeycombs loaded with potassium-promoted cobalt hydrotalcite and with ceria-based rhodium-palladium catalysts were tested under different reactant loads. The hydrogen yield obtained over the cobalt-based catalytic honeycomb at low load (F/W < 25 mLliq·g-1cat·h-1, GHSV = 4·102 h-1) was remarkably high, whereas that obtained over the noble metal-based catalytic honeycombs was much superior at high loads (F/W = 25-150 mLliq·g-1cat·h-1, GHSV = 4·102-2.4·103 h-1). At higher reactant loads the overall hydrogen prodn. was limited by heat transfer from the exhaust heat to the reformer inside the housing of the exhaust gas pipe of the ICE. Extensive carbon deposition occurred over the cobalt-based honeycomb, making its use impractical. In contrast, stability runs (>200 h) at high load (F/W = 150 mLliq·g-1cat·h-1, GHSV = 2.4·103 h-1) showed that promotion of the ceria-supported noble metal catalyst with alumina and zirconia is a key element for practical application using com. bioethanol. HRTEM anal. of post mortem honeycombs loaded with RhPd/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2-Al2O3 showed no carbon formation and no metal agglomeration.

Several reactions can contributed to the overall process of exhaust gas reforming, during which some of the engine fuel is catalytically converted mainly to H2 and CO. If the predominant reactions are endothermic, the process acts as a means of exhaust-heat recovery, and the fuel heating value is raised. When using conventional gasoline or diesel fuel, the reforming catalyst is required to promote steam-and dry-reforming, at the expense of the exothermic reactions-water gas shift, methanation, partial oxidn. and combustion. In this study we show that a precious metal formulation is capable of catalyzing most of the key reforming routes with the exception of the water gas shift reaction, under the set of conditions that we have used to simulate an exhaust from a bioethanol-fulled spark ignition engine. Our results predict that the overall process of exhaust gas reforming of C2H5OH will be oxidative, and yet waste heat will be consumed. The expected increase in fuel heating value is 6%, but can rise towards 20% if there is less O2 available in the exhaust, allowing more of the bioethanol to react by steam- and dry-reforming in the catalyst bed. By feeding the reformate back to the engine, the intention is to improve the fuel economy and emission quality.

This paper describes the design, manufg., operation, and optimization of a mobile ethanol reformer fuel cell system for off-grid power prodn. The reformer system includes an autothermal reformer, high and low temp. shift reactors, a selective methanation reactor, and a tail gas combustor. A min. amt. of process controls and little internal heat integration kept system architecture simple. Process simulations provided optimal operating parameters, expected hydrogen yield, and system efficiency. The reformer temp. was selected to be 730 °C with minimal methane prodn. and no soot formation in the reactor. The oxygen-to-steam ratio is detd. by the temp. of feed streams, reforming temp. and heat losses. It was set to be in the order of 0.9. The steam-to-carbon ratio has no impact on carbon monoxide concn. (on a dry basis) in the reformer system product gas, i.e. at the outlet of the selective methanation reactor. Therefore, it was selected to be 2.5, sufficiently high to avoid soot formation in the reforming reactor and yet small enough to keep the size of the water evaporator in a sensible range. The reformer fuel cell system was operated in a lab environment and all reactors were thoroughly investigated. Main focus was to keep the carbon monoxide concn. at the outlet of the selective methanation reactor below 10 ppmv at all times. Furthermore, start-up and shut down procedures were optimized to minimize degrdn. of the catalysts. Finally, the complete reformer fuel cell system was operated to investigate its performance. System controls allowed fully automated operation of the integrated reformer fuel cell system.

Power required to run auxiliary systems on a passenger car, such as those for air conditioning and advanced vehicle control, reduces the driving range of a vehicle equipped with a hybrid drive train. Under practical driving conditions, a significant amt. of addnl. energy is required at low power levels compared to the rated power of the drive unit. In the present study, a fuel cell-battery drive train augmented by an on-board fuel (ethanol) processor to provide the motoring power requirements of a car is considered. Using systematic driving cycle simulations that take account of power-to-wt., energy-to-wt. and power-to-efficiency factors of on-board power sources under simulated load conditions, it is shown that a combination of steadily-operated compact ethanol reformer, a low-power battery continuously charged by excess reformer capacity and a high-power fuel cell powered by conservatively-used hydrogen from cylinder can increase the range of hybrid fuel cell drivetrains to about 750 km. Although the overall energy consumption of the three-way hybrid is more than that of fuel cell-battery hybrid, lesser use of stored hydrogen improves the fuel economy of the hybrid drivetrain. While the system complexity is increased, long-range distressed mode operation becomes feasible with the added fuel processor.

We exptl. studied a high temp. proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell to investigate the effects of CO poisoning at different temps. The effects of temp., for various percentages of CO mixed with anode hydrogen stream, on the current-voltage characteristics of the fuel cell are investigated. The results show that at low temp., the fuel cell performance degraded significantly with higher CO percentage (i.e., 5% CO) in the anode hydrogen stream compared to the high temp. A detailed electrochem. anal. regarding CO coverage on electrode surface is presented which indicates that electrochem. oxidn. is favorable at high temp. A cell diagnostic test shows that both 2% CO and 5% CO can be tolerated equally at low c.d. (<0.3 A cm-2) with high cell voltage (>0.5 V) at 180 °C without any cell performance loss. At high temp., both 2% CO and 5% CO can be tolerated at higher c.d. (>0.5 A cm-2) with moderate cell voltage (0.2-0.5 V) when the cell voltage loss within 0.03-0.05 V would be acceptable. The surface coverage of platinum catalyst by CO at low temp. is very high compared to high temp. Results suggest that the PEM fuel cell operating at 180 °C or above, the reformate gas with higher CO percentage (i.e., 2-5%) can be fed to the cell directly from the fuel processor.

The current status on the understanding of the various operational aspects of high temp. proton exchange membrane fuel cells (HT-PEMFC) has been summarized. The paper focuses on phosphoric acid-doped polybenzimidazole (PBI)-based HT-PEMFCs and an overview of the common practices of their design and characterization techniques at single cell, stack and system levels is given. The state-of-the-art concepts of different degrdn. mechanisms and methods of their mitigation are also discussed. Moreover, accelerated stress testing (AST) procedures for HT-PEMFCs available in literature are outlined. Catalyst degrdn. and electrolyte loss take place at higher rates in the beginning of life of the fuel cell. This is due to the smaller size of Pt particles and the presence of excess phosphoric acid in the beginning of life that favor the resp. degrdn. Therefore, the redistribution of phosphoric acid in the membrane and the electrodes is crucial for the proper activation of the fuel cell, and a startup procedure should take this into account in order to avoid beginning of life degrdn. Online monitoring of the fuel cell system's state of health using diagnostic tools can help detect fuel cell faults for targeted interventions based on the obsd. conditions to prevent sudden failures and to prolong the fuel cell's lifetime. However, the technol. is still under development and robust online diagnostics tools are hardly available. Currently, mitigation is mainly done based on favorable operating conditions and techniques to recover degrdn. and the development of more resistant components that can withstand the known degrdn. mechanisms.

A review on steam reforming of ethanol for prodn. of hydrogen for fuel cells. Process engineering aspects of ethanol steam reforming are discussed. High temps., low pressures and high water-to-ethanol ratios in the feed favor hydrogen prodn. Ni, Co, Ni/Cu, and noble metal (Pd, Pt, Rh) supported catalysts are promising. Major concerns are fast catalyst coking and formation of byproducts such as methane, di-Et ether, and acetaldehyde. To overcome these problems, the process should be carried out in a two-layer fixed bed catalytic reactor; first, ethanol should be dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde in presence of Cu-based catalyst at 573-673 K and then this stream should be passed over a bed contg. a mixt. of Ni-based catalyst and a chemisorbent at low temps. of ∼723 K. The entire process of ethanol steam reforming coupled with selective CO2 removal by chemisorption will enable prodn. of high-purity H2 and hence is very promising.

All alcs. could produce H2 at 70-90% selectivity, and Rh-Ce was superior to Rh in producing H2. Rapid adsorption of alcs. as alkoxy species leads to complete dissocn. to H2 and CO. Probably acetone and olefins likely were produced primarily by homogeneous reactions after all O2 were consumed in the catalyst. Ethanol is a renewable, portable, and non-toxic liq. that is a possible source of hydrogen for PEM fuel cells. This work describes an auto-thermal flat plate catalytic wall reactor for steam reforming of ethanol into H2 and CO2. Catalytic methane combustion on Pt is coupled to ethanol steam reforming on Rh and Rh-Ce across an auto-thermal wall. At a steam/carbon ratio of 3/1 the reactor gave >99% conversion of ethanol. An H2/CO ratio of 3/1 was obtained at a residence time of ∼100 ms and an upstream temp. of ∼800 °C. Methane selectivities of less than 1% were obtained with Rh-Ce. Water-gas shift was also considered in order to increase the H2/CO ratio. The reactor was lengthened to include a cooler water-gas shift section using a Pt-Ce catalyst. The extended reactor produced >99% conversion of ethanol and an H2/CO ratio of 30/1 at a steam/carbon ratio of 4/1. The residence time was ∼400 ms, and the upstream temp. was ∼900 °C in the extended reactor. The reactor was stable for at least 100 h with no detectable degrdn. in performance.
