Of these elements, K-, P-, and Mg-doped ethanol operated autothermally over the 6 h test period, whereas Si, S, Na, and Ca quenched the reaction. The ability of the catalyst to be regenerated after doping was investigated by switching to inorg.-free fuel. Regeneration was possible for each of the inorgs. studied. Silicon shut down autothermal operation the fastest, but complete regeneration of the catalyst was achieved by passing pure ethanol. Sulfur caused extensive coke formation and disintegration of the α-Al2O3 support. Phosphorus increased ethanol dehydration to ethylene, indicating acid chem., which was observable even upon regeneration. Sodium and potassium increased acetaldehyde selectivities because of their basic nature. Calcium and magnesium accumulated at the front face of the catalyst, forming CaCO3 and MgO, resp. Low-sulfur hydrocarbon fuels can be converted to fuel cell grade H using a compact fuel processor architecture. The necessary high volumetric activity water gas shift (WGS) catalysts (Pt on ceria-zirconia) reacts CO-rich reformate with steam to yield H2 and CO2. Such highly selective non-pyrophoric noble metal catalysts, including Ce1-x-yZrxMyO2 (typically x = 0-0.42, y = 0.08; M = Mo, Nb, Ta, W), were developed through coordinated at. modeling, syntheses, structural characterization, kinetic performance tests, and micro-kinetic analyses. D. functional simulations made with the VASP code suggested that the undoped catalyst WGS activity would be limited by the strong binding of CO intermediates, blocking the reoxidn. of the reduced oxide by water. These predictions were confirmed by in situ cylindrical internal reflection-Fourier transform IR spectroscopy and by micro-kinetic analyses of the micro-reactor results. The efficacy of Mo-doped ceria-zirconia compns. was confirmed at lower temps. in replicated catalyst synthesis-reactor studies.

We have examd. the water-gas-shift reaction over noble metals and metals with ceria for catalyst contact times between 0.008 and 0.05 s for temps. from 300 to 1000 °C. With reactants of CO, H2, and H2O at a 1/2/4 compn., the reaction approached equil. at these contact times for temps. as low as 380 °C, which corresponds to a 50/1 H2/CO ratio. All results follow the equil. conversion vs. temp. curve at high temps. and then the rate decreases rapidly as temp. decreases. All metals show considerable promotion upon ceria addn., with Pt/ceria showing the most promise in terms of promotion, stability, and lack of methanation activity. A simple kinetic model that assumes first-order reversible reaction in all species fits all data at all temps. from equil. to low conversions. The rate is nearly independent of surface area over a wide variation of parameters, and rates indicate that mass-transfer limitations are not dominant.

Fuel processing systems that are used in conjunction with polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cells require high activity water gas shift (WGS) catalysts that remove carbon monoxide, a poison for membranes in the fuel cell stacks. WGS activity of various noble metals supported on cubic, nanocryst., high surface area, large pore ceria-zirconia was measured at a space velocity of 312,000 h-1, under two feed gas compns. that simulated the high temp. shift (HTS) and the low temp. shift (LTS) conditions found in a typical fuel processing system. The (HTS) feed compn. was 4.9% CO, 10.5% CO2, 33% H2O, 30.3% H2; and the low temp. gas compn. (LTS) was 1.5% CO, 5% CO2, 45% H2O, 25% H2, with the balance of the stream being N2 in both cases. The activity trend under both feed gases over a broad range of temps. (200°-320°) was Pt > Rh > Ru ∼ Pd > Ir > Au. This trend did not agree with those previously reported in literature or with CO uptake data for these samples. We hypothesize that this reflects the dominance of different reaction mechanisms under different gas compns. and temps. The discrepancy in the activities obsd. in this study and those reported in literature might also be attributed to differences in the synthesis techniques of the oxide supports and metal loading. Our study also found that the turnover rate (TOR) for the Pt catalyst was maximized in the range between 1-2% loading under both HTS and LTS conditions.

The av. structure and the local structure of nanocryst. Rh-doped CeO2 catalysts, prepd. using a co-pptn. method, were studied using a set of structural (PDF, HRTEM, XRD) and spectral (XPS, Raman spectroscopy) methods. The samples with Rh content <10%, calcined at 450°, were homogeneous solid solns. A comparison of the exptl. results and pair distribution function (PDF) modeling data showed that Rh3+ substitutes Ce4+ ions in the fluorite phase. Charge equil. is obtained by the O vacancy for each Rh3+ cation introduced into the ceria cell. The solid soln. demonstrated high catalytic activity in low-temp. CO oxidn. (LTO CO). The solid solns. were stable only in a nanocryst. state and decompd. upon thermal treatment. The calcination of the solid soln. at T > 450° results in a decrease in the catalytic activity that is accompanied by Rh assocn. in the subsurface area and strong distortion of the anionic subcell. At T = 800° α-Rh2O3 nanoparticles are formed on the surface of the fluorite phase. The XRD-detectable Rh oxide phases are formed after calcination at 1000°. Some parts of Rh within the subsurface RhxCe1-xO2-δ solid soln. remain and they preserve catalytic properties for low-temp. oxidn.

The affinity order among four kinds of major noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, and Pt) and CeO2 was investigated by XRD and XAFS techniques. Development work for a compact hydrogen supply system with a thermal output of 65 kW applying ethanol as fuel was started by IMM in collaboration with Rosetti Marino, an Italian plant engineering company. This work describes the development of a compact ethanol fuel processor for small scale high temp. polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (HT-PEMFC) systems with 200-500 W elec. power output. Promising markets for reformer fuel cell systems based on ethanol are mobile or portable leisure and security power supply applications as well as small scale stationary off grid power supply and backup power. Main components of the fuel processor to be developed were the reformer reactor, the shift converter, a catalytic burner and heat exchangers. Development focused in particular on the homogeneous evapn. of the liq. reactants ethanol and water for the reformer and burner and on the development of an efficient start-up method, resp. Theor. as well as exptl. work has been carried out for all main components sep. including for example catalyst screening and evaporator performance tests in a first project period. Afterwards all components have been assembled to a complete fuel processor which has been qualified with various operation parameter set-ups. A theor. defined basic operation point could practically be confirmed. The overall start-up time to receive reformate gas with appropriate quality to feed an HT-PEMFC (xCO < 2%) takes around 30 min. At steady state operation the hydrogen power output is around 900 W with H2 and CO fractions of 41.2% and 1.5%, resp.

In recent years, hydrogen prodn. from renewable feed-stocks attracts particular attention. Specifically, the steam reforming of biomass-derived bioethanol could provide H2-rich effluent streams, representing an interesting research field. This study focuses on the development of bimetallic structured catalysts (contg. Ni and Pt as active species and supported on ceria and ceria-zirconia) active in Ethanol Steam Reforming (ESR) reaction at low-temp. (300-600 °C) and characterized by improved heat transfer properties. ESR reaction was carried out on ceramic foams and, as a comparison, on powders catalysts. In particular, catalytic tests were carried out on two reactor configurations: catalytic powders were tested in both a tubular and annular reactor; in addn., the tubular configuration was also employed for the structured catalysts. Unsatisfactory results were obsd. for powders in the tubular reactor while the better thermal management of the annular configuration ensured significantly higher conversions. Moreover, the enhanced thermal cond. of SiC foams catalysts, tested in the tubular reactor, allowed overcoming heat transfer limitations in an easy reactor geometry, resulting in very good performances. The catalytic behavior of bimetallic CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 based catalysts was also compared and the effect of catalytic support on ethanol conversion and H2 yield at different space velocities (100,000-400,000 h-1) was investigated. Finally, Pt-Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts, which displayed a more interesting catalytic activity with respect to CeO2 based samples, were employed for stability tests at 100,000 h-1 and 450 °C: products gas distribution was not affected during TOS and total ethanol conversion was recorded for almost 5 h.

Novel catalytic reactor for oxidative reforming of methanol
Lyubovsky, Maxim; Roychoudhury, Subir

Oxidative steam reforming of methanol is shown to produce extremely high hydrogen yield. Specific hydrogen prodn. rates as high as 425 kWt/L of reactor vol. were demonstrated in a novel Microlith-based catalytic reactor. At reduced space velocities hydrogen concn. in the reformate stream was as high as 50%, while CO concn. was as low as 1.2%. The thermal efficiency of the oxidative steam reforming process is >80%. It is shown that the autothermal oxidative steam reforming process consists of three reactions: methanol oxidn., methanol decompn., and water gas shift. These reactions have different kinetic rates and progress in an overlapping sequence along the catalyst bed. A radial flow catalyst configuration enables varying gas flow velocity to accommodate the different kinetic rates and heat release characteristics of these reactions. This allows a flat temp. profile and approach to equil. product compn. to be achieved in a single catalyst bed.

A review on reforming bio-ethanol for hydrogen production
Ni, Meng; Leung, Dennis Y. C.; Leung, Michael K. H.
International Journal of Hydrogen Energy

A review. Bio-ethanol is a prosperous renewable energy carrier mainly produced from biomass fermn. Reforming of bio-ethanol provides a promising method for hydrogen prodn. from renewable resources. Besides operating conditions, the use of catalysts plays a crucial role in hydrogen prodn. through ethanol reforming. Rh and Ni are so far the best and the most commonly used catalysts for ethanol steam reforming towards hydrogen prodn. The selection of proper support for catalyst and the methods of catalyst prepn. significantly affect the activity of catalysts. In terms of hydrogen prodn. and long-term stability, MgO, ZnO, CeO2, and La2O3 are suitable supports for Rh and Ni due to their basic characteristics, which favor ethanol dehydrogenation but inhibit dehydration. As Rh and Ni are inactive for water gas shift reaction (WGSR), the development of bimetallic catalysts, alloy catalysts, and double-bed reactors is promising to enhance hydrogen prodn. and long-term catalyst stability. Autothermal reforming of bio-ethanol has the advantages of lesser external heat input and long-term stability. Its overall efficiency needs to be further enhanced, as part of the ethanol feedstock is used to provide low-grade thermal energy. Development of millisecond-contact time reactor provides a low-cost and effective way to reform bio-ethanol and hydrocarbons for fuel upgrading. Despite its early R&D stage, bio-ethanol reforming for hydrogen prodn. shows promises for its future fuel cell applications.

Deposition of γ-Al2O3 washcoats onto Al and FeCrAlloy supports in the form of slabs and onto α-Al2O3 tubes was performed according to a two-step procedure involving: (a) deposition of a boehmite primer, and (b) deposition of the γ-Al2O3 layer, both by dip coating into powder dispersions in HNO3 aq. solns. We present herein data concerning the effects of the major prepn. variables (HNO3 and H2O concns. in the dispersion, withdrawal velocity, drying temp., no. of dipping cycles, calcination temp.) on the deposited coating load and on the adherence of the washcoat. Based on a rheol. characterization of the γ-Al2O3 dispersions, we propose also a correlation between their apparent viscosity and the washcoat load. Finally, we briefly illustrate the activity in catalytic combustion reactions of structured Pd-based catalysts prepd. according to the investigated washcoating methods.

A series of Ru catalysts supported on cordierite monoliths, ceramic foams and γ-Al2O3 pellets was prepd. and tested for the prodn. of hydrogen by catalytic partial oxidn. of ethanol. The catalyst supported on a cordierite monolith exhibited excellent catalytic performance for a wide variety of process conditions and excellent long-term stability with low coke formation. The effect of the steam/ethanol molar ratio on conversion and selectivity was relatively small. A more pronounced effect was obsd. for the oxygen/ethanol ratio. Overall, the catalysts on all three supports were able to convert ethanol completely with high selectivity towards the desired products. The Ru supported on a ceramic foam catalyst provided comparatively better performance, probably due to the smaller pore sizes and higher tortuosity of this support.

Lee, Hye-Jin; Kim, Byoung Gak; Lee, Dong Hoon; Park, Se Jin; Kim, Yongmin; Lee, Jeung Woo; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Nam, Suk Woo; Kim, Hyoung-Juhn; Kim, Hwayong; Kim, Ju-Yong

Acid-doped polybenzimidazole (PBI) membrane and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)-based electrodes are used for the membrane electrode assembly (MEA) in high-temp. polymer electrolyte fuel cells (HTPEFCs). To find the optimum PTFE content for the catalyst layer, the PTFE ratio in the electrodes is varied from 25 to 50%. To improve the performance of the electrodes, PBI is added to the catalyst layer. With a wt. ratio of PTFE to Pt/C of 45:55 (45% PTFE in the catalyst layer), the fuel cell shows good performance at 150° under non-humidified conditions. When 5% PBI is added to the electrodes, performance is further improved (250 mA/cm2 at 0.6 V). The 20 W class HTPEFC stack is fabricated with a novel MEA. This MEA consists of 8 layers (1 H3PO4-doped PBI membrane, 2 electrodes, 1 sub-gasket, 2 gas-diffusion media, 2 gas-sealing gaskets). The sub-gasket mitigates the destruction of a highly acid-doped PBI membrane and provides long-term durability to the fuel cell stack. The stack operated for 1200 h without noticeable cell degrdn.

Hydrogen production by thermal partial oxidation of hydrocarbon fuels in porous media based reformer
Al-Hamamre, Z.; Voss, S.; Trimis, D.

The thermal partial oxidn. process of methane was studied numerically and exptl. Thermodn. calcns. and kinetic simulation were performed using CHEMKIN tools to det. the practical operating conditions. Exptl., a porous material-based reactor was built to perform the partial oxidn. process. Temp. profiles along the reactor central axis and concn. profiles of CO, H2, CO2, C2H2 and CH4 were measured. Two different porous structures were installed in the reaction zone: Al2O3 fiber static mixer structures and SiC foams. The effects of air preheating temp., thermal load and air ratio on the reforming process were studied for both structures. The numerical calcn. showed that an air ratio down to 0.4 is a practical limit to perform the partial oxidn. process. Exptl., the air preheating temp. has no significant influence on the syngas compn.; however, it does affect the soot point (λ c). Higher heat recuperation was detected in the case of SiC foam based reformer than in the case of the Al2O3 mixer one. The SiC foam based reactor showed also a better performance than the Al2O3 regarding the soot point. For air preheating temp. of 700°, the current soot point for the SiC foam based reformer was 0.42, while it was 0.45 for the Al2O3 mixer one.
